snippet: Although exporting its vast oil supply would give the Kurdish government leverage in its push for sovereignty, opposition from other nations has left the region’s future uncertain.
abstract: Iraq's autonomous Kurdish region appears closer than ever to attaining its centuries-old dream of statehood after seizing control of oil-rich city of Kirkuk; bid for statehood, however, presents array of problems, including difficulty Kurds face in selling its abundant oil supplies abroad.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Erbil and Istanbul, and Clifford Krauss from Houston.

lead_paragraph: Although exporting its vast oil supply would give the Kurdish government leverage in its push for sovereignty, opposition from other nations has left the region’s future uncertain.

headline.main: Poised to Gain in Iraq Crisis, Kurds Face New Barriers to Autonomy
headline.print_headline: Poised to Gain in Iraq Crisis, Kurds Face New Barriers to Autonomy

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
